title: How to Marble a Bottle

methods.name: Marbling the Inside of a Bottle

steps.headline: Clean a glass bottle with soap and water.
steps.description: Wash the bottle, inside and out, with dish soap and warm water. Be sure to remove any labels stuck to the outside of the bottle as well. Allow the bottle to air dry before continuing. This technique will give you a smooth, chip-free finish on the outside. Unfortunately, you can't add water to the bottle, or the paint will flake.

steps.headline: Pour 2 to 3 colors of acrylic craft paint into the bottle.
steps.description: How much paint you use depends on the size of the bottle. In general, 1 to 3 tablespoons (15 to 44 ml) total will be plenty. Keep in mind that you can always add more paint to the bottle after the first layer dries. Choose the colors with care. They will blend together in some areas. Contrasting colors look great next to each other, but they also make brown when mixed. For instance, you may choose to use blue, white, and purple, or red, yellow, and white.

steps.headline: Tilt and rotate the bottle to distribute the paint.
steps.description: Tilt the bottle left, right, up, and down, so that the paint coats the sides. Turn the bottle on its side, and roll it back and forth across the table to help further distribute the paint. If you are worried about the paint coming out of the bottle, put the cap or cork on first.

steps.headline: Pour the excess paint into a jar.
steps.description: Rotate the bottle as you pour the paint into the jar to help coat the neck of the bottle as well. Stand the bottle upright when you are done. Don’t worry if you still have some paint inside the bottle. It will dry and won’t affect the design on the outside. Stir the paint in the jar to create a new color, then close the jar and save it for another project. Swirl the paint inside the jar to create a marbled jar instead. Now you’ll have a jar to match your bottle!

steps.headline: Wipe any spills on the outside of the bottle with a damp paper towel.
steps.description: You may have gotten some paint on the outside of the bottle's neck when you poured it into the jar. Use a damp paper towel to wipe up any paint on the outside before it dries. If the paint dries on the bottle before you can get to it, don’t worry. Glass is a smooth surface, so you should be able to scrape the paint off with your fingernail.

steps.headline: Set the bottle upright on a paper towel and let it dry for about 1 week.
steps.description: After a couple of days, insert a wooden skewer into the bottle, poke the bottom, then pull it out. If the skewer comes out clean, the paint is dry and the bottle is ready to use. If it comes out colored, the paint is wet and needs to dry longer. Leave the bottle alone for a couple more days before checking it again. It may take longer for the paint to dry, especially if it is humid where you live. If you made a marbled jar, turn it upside down on wax paper to drain the excess paint first, then let it dry upright. This could take at least 1 day.

steps.headline: Use the bottle as a decoration, not a vase.
steps.description: If you fill it with water, the paint may dissolve or chip away. Instead, place the bottle on a mantle, table, or bookshelf. If you wish to put something instead of it, try some fake or dried flowers instead. If you notice any bare patches on your bottle, you can pour 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of one of the colors you used, swirl the paint inside the bottle, drain it out, then let it dry.

methods.name: Marbling the Outside of the Bottle

steps.headline: Clean the outside of the bottle, then wipe it down with rubbing alcohol.
steps.description: Clean the bottle with dish soap and warm water. Remove any labels and residue left by the labels. Wipe the bottle down using a paper towel soaked in rubbing alcohol to remove any oily residue, then let it dry. The good thing about using this method is that the inside of the bottle will be waterproof, so you can use is as a vase for fresh flowers. The downside is that the paint can get chipped and scratched easily.

steps.headline: Paint the bottle using a white, glossy spray paint.
steps.description: Take the bottle outside or into a well-ventilated area. Cover your work surface with newspaper, then set the bottle on top. Shake the can for a few seconds, then apply a light even coat. Hold the can several inches/centimeters away from the bottle. Check the label to find out how far you should hold the can as each brand will be different. You can use a different color of spray paint if you prefer, such as black. Make sure that it contrasts with the other colors that you will be using.

steps.headline: Let the paint dry, then apply a second coat, if needed.
steps.description: It is better to apply several light coats of paint rather than a single thick coat. This will reduce drips, runs, and puddles. If you wish to paint the bottom of the bottle, do so after the sides dry.

steps.headline: Fill a plastic bucket with room temperature water.
steps.description: Choose a bucket that is taller than your bottle, then fill it with water. The water needs to be deep enough so that you can dip your bottle inside without the bottle touching the bottom of the bucket.

steps.headline: Pour some nail polish into the water.
steps.description: You can use as many colors as you want, but 1 or 2 will look the best. How much nail polish you pour is also up to you; the more you add, the more marbling you will get. If you want to, you can gently swirl the nail polish colors together with a wooden skewer. Move quickly onto the next step so that the nail polish doesn’t dry on the surface of the water. Flat, glossy colors will work the best, but you can try pearlescent ones as well. She is a 12 year blogging veteran who loves making crafting and DIY as easy as possible for others, with a focus on mindfulness in making. Claire Donovan-Blackwood			Crafting Expert, Heart Handmade UK				You can use either nail polish or spray paint for a marbled bottle. If it’s a small bottle, nail polish will work well, but for a larger bottle, spray paint will be more economical.

steps.headline: Dip the bottle into the water, then pull it out.
steps.description: How deep you dip the bottle depends on how far up the bottle you want the marbling to go. If you want the marbling the extend all the way to the top of the bottle, dip the bottle all the way in. If you want the marbling to only go up halfway, then dip the bottle halfway in. Hold the bottle by the very tip. Don't let any water get inside the bottle. Alternatively, you can roll the bottle across the surface of the water. This technique takes a little more practice, however.

steps.headline: Set the bottle onto a sheet of wax paper or parchment paper so that it can dry.
steps.description: After about 10 minutes, tap the marbled design to make sure that it is dry, then wipe off any excess water with a paper towel. If the bottle feels tacky, it is not dry, and you should wait longer before wiping it.

steps.headline: Pick up the excess nail polish from the water with a wooden skewer.
steps.description: Do not pour the water into the sink, or you risk clogging it. Instead, swirl a wooden skewer or paper towel in the water to catch the excess nail polish, then throw it away. Once all of the nail polish is out of the water, you can pour the water out.
